title: You eat food everyday but would you invest in improving it?
text:
Most of us buy food pretty much every day, but would you invest in it?

We think nothing of funds and investment trusts that back a wide variety of specific things, from investing in Vietnam to biotech firms, but when I told people I was interviewing a food and agriculture fund manager their ears pricked up.

This is funny when you consider that not only do we need to eat every day but we also place food at the heart of so much that we do.

Food lies at the heart of so much that we do, but we rarely think much about where it comes from and its impact in too much detail let alone considering investing in it

I found the discussion with Henry Boucher, of Sarasin Food and Agriculture Opportunities Fund, for a recent Investing Show a fascinating one to do.

‘No one really knows much about the world of food, but it’s a vast area of change and if you are investing for opportunities then you want change,’ he said.

And while at a first pass you may not automatically place producing and selling food high on a list of the most dynamic markets, when you think about it the world of food has changed swiftly and dramatically – and is likely to continue to do so.

From field to fork, the food chain massively impacts how we live and there is mounting pressure to reconsider the post-war rush to industrial farming, as we face issues ranging from food shortages, to food security and climate change.

To take just one example, veganism and eating meat has become one of the hottest topics in the debate over climate change.

Some campaigners are passionate in their claims that people must stop eating meat altogether, others say we should just eat substantially less, and others point out that science shows it is how the meat is produced that really matters (albeit even scientists can’t fully agree on the extent of that).

Pasture fed animals are generally considered better for combating climate change, but an influential University of Oxford Food Climate Research Network report in 2017 said for cattle this was overstated, while another report this summer from Oxford Martin School, at Oxford University, said conventional global warming potential measures were misleading for ruminant livestock.

Britain’s farmers are keen to point out how the nation is among those leading the way on lowering carbon emissions from agriculture – and that farming is an emissions source but it is also a solution as it can capture carbon dioxide.

The NFU's graphic highlights how farming contributes to and combats climate change

But even within the UK’s farmers there is a fierce debate about where the balance of future efforts should lie between sustainable and environmentally-friendly farming and feeding the nation, while earning a crust as supermarket price wars drive earnings ever lower.

These arguments will continue for years to come, but what is clear is how much the way we farm and produce food has changed over a relatively short period of time.

Earlier this year I read Isabella Tree’s intriguing book Wilding, about abandoning trying to eke out a steadily diminishing living from farming on a West Sussex estate and turning it back to nature instead.

It also tells the history of how industrial farming developed after the Second World War, with more machinery, bigger fields, the ballooning use of fertiliser and more intensive agriculture stripping land of its nutrients and ripping up the natural landscape.

As with many things that we’ve done over the past hundred-odd years, this raised living standards but caused a lot of a damage – to plants, animals and the atmosphere - and now the world is waking up to the need to change.

At the same time, Henry says, we have ‘long-term slightly hidden trends’ in the world of food that create ‘tailwinds’.

He said: ‘Those tailwinds include population growth, it includes things like urbanisation - as people move to the cities their diets change because they’ve got more access to supermarkets and things like that, and it includes just the rising standards of living across the world and the changes in our habits and in our health trends and concerns.’

These are all things that make you stop and think a lot more about how the things we eat or drink get to our mouths – and whether they offer the opportunity to act to improve the world we live, the possibility of investing to make a profit, or the chance to do both at the same time.
